author: Simon Mones
title: Schumachers Urlaubs-Idylle zerst√∂rt - ‚ÄûEs ist eine Schande"
text:
Schumachers Urlaubs-Idylle zerst√∂rt ‚Äì ‚ÄûEs ist eine Schande‚Äú
Die Schumachers besitzen auf Mallorca ein luxuri√∂ses Anwesen. Auch Michael Schumacher wird zur Erholung immer wieder eingeflogen. Doch die Ruhe wird massiv gest√∂rt.
Gland/Port d‚ÄôAndratx ‚Äì Kaum eine Insel hat so eine hohe Anziehungskraft auf deutsche Urlauber und Auswanderer wie Mallorca. Besonders das √ñrtchen Port d‚ÄòAndratx erfreut sicher hoher Beliebtheit. In der exklusiven Hafenstadt haben auch zahlreiche Stars und Sternchen ein Anwesen ‚Äì darunter auch Michael Schumacher.
Das Anwesen der Familie Schumacher befindet sich weit √ºber dem Nobelhafen und z√§hlt zu den sch√∂nsten Grundst√ºcken Mallorcas. Die Villa auf Mallorca, die sich seit 2018 im Besitz der Familie befindet, wird jedoch regelm√§√üig von Familienmitgliedern genutzt. Und auch der Rekordweltmeister wird immer wieder eingeflogen, um die Ruhe der spanischen Insel zu genie√üen. Doch seit einiger Zeit ist es damit vorbei.
Neubauprojekt st√∂rt Ruhe rund um Schumacher-Anwesen
Der Grund: ein gro√ües Neubauprojekt. Daf√ºr wird derzeit in unmittelbarer N√§he zum Schumacher-Anwesen ein Berghang abgetragen. ‚ÄûEs dr√∂hnt durch den ganzen Hafen. Der L√§rm ist bis nach Camp de Mar zu h√∂ren. Es ist unertr√§glich‚Äú, berichtet eine deutsche Anwohnerin der Mallorca Zeitung.
Das Ausma√ü der Bauarbeiten ist betr√§chtlich. ‚ÄûNun haben sie jedoch ein riesiges Loch vor der Nase. Der ganze Berg wird bebaut und zerst√ºckelt. Nur ein Teil bleibt noch unverschont, weil die Zugangsstra√üe fehlt. Es ist eine Schande‚Äú, klagt die Anwohnerin weiter. Lediglich im Sommer sei es ruhiger. Denn im Juli und August d√ºrfen laute Baumaschienen nicht benutzt werden. Die Arbeiten dauern noch bis Februar 2026 an.
Michael Schumacher verbringt die meiste Zeit am Genfer See
Ob sich die Schumachers eben so am Baul√§rm st√∂ren, ist unklar. Michael Schumacher selbst verbringt die meiste Zeit des Jahres ohnehin in seinem Anwesen am Genfer See in der Schweiz, wo er seit seinem schweren Skiunfall im Dezember 2013 betreut wird. Seither haben nur noch weniger Menschen Zugang zu dem Rekordweltmeister.
Ein ehemaliger Weggef√§hrte Schumachers √§u√üerte k√ºrzlich Besorgnis √ºber den Gesundheitszustand des siebenmaligen Formel-1-Weltmeisters. Die genauen Umst√§nde bleiben jedoch weiterhin privat. Ein Ex-Teamkollege erkl√§rte in diesem Zusammenhang, dass die sp√§rlichen Informationen zum Gesundheitszustand Schumachers dem Wunsch der Familie nach Privatsph√§re geschuldet seien. (smo)

author: New York Times
title: Israeli-American Thought to Be a Hostage Was Killed on Oct. 7, Her Family Says
text:
Judih Weinstein Haggai, a 70-year-old who was believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas, was actually killed during the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, her family and Kibbutz Nir Oz said in statements on Thursday.
Ms. Haggai‚Äôs husband, Gadi Haggai, had also been listed as a hostage but the Hostages and Missing Persons Families Forum announced last week that he, too, was killed in the attacks.
The forum said the couple were shot while on their morning walk through the fields of the kibbutz, and that Ms. Haggai had managed to inform friends that they had been injured, her husband critically so.
Ms. Haggai was, in fact, fatally wounded, and her death has now been confirmed, Kibbutz Nir Oz said on Thursday. Its statement did not specify how it learned that she had died in the attack.
The couple‚Äôs bodies are being held by Hamas, according to the kibbutz, their family and the Hostages and Missing Persons Families Forum. The groups said the couple were citizens of both Israel and the United States, and that Ms. Haggai also had Canadian citizenship.
President Biden said he and Jill Biden, the first lady, were holding the couple‚Äôs ‚Äúfour children, seven grandchildren and other loved ones close to our hearts.‚Äù
‚ÄúI will never forget what their daughter, and the family members of other Americans held hostage in Gaza, have shared with me,‚Äù he said in a statement . ‚ÄúThey have been living through hell for weeks.‚Äù
Ms. Haggai would be remembered ‚Äúfor the creative life she built with her husband,‚Äù her family said, adding that ‚Äútheir murders are a reminder for leaders everywhere to bring the hostages home now before it is too late.‚Äù
The post Israeli-American Thought to Be a Hostage Was Killed on Oct. 7, Her Family Says appeared first on New York Times .

author: Delbert Martin
title: Find out how to Keep away from Reward Shopping Stress with On-line Shopping
text:
Reward shopping generally is a joyful expertise, but it typically becomes a source of stress‚Äîespecially when juggling busy schedules, crowded stores, and the pressure to search out the proper item. On-line shopping presents a robust answer to this problem, making it simpler, faster, and more handy to check off everybody on your list without the usual headaches. Right here‚Äôs easy methods to reduce stress and actually enjoy the process of present giving, all thanks to the benefits of online shopping.
Plan Ahead and Save Time
One of many top stressors throughout gift shopping is time pressure. When you shop on-line, you possibly can start early and take your time without rushing through store aisles. By planning a number of weeks ahead, you get access to a broader choice, early bird reductions, and more relaxed choice-making. Many e-commerce platforms permit you to save items to a wishlist or cart, so you possibly can revisit and make remaining selections while you‚Äôre ready. This kind of flexibility merely doesn‚Äôt exist while you‚Äôre shopping in person under pressure.
Shop Anytime, Anywhere
The comfort of 24/7 access is among the greatest advantages of online gift shopping. Whether or not you‚Äôre on a lunch break, commuting, or enjoyable at home in the evening, you can browse, compare, and buy items from your laptop or mobile device. There is not any have to carve out time for a mall journey or battle for parking space. This flexibility helps reduce stress, especially throughout the vacation season or for last-minute gifts.
Keep away from the Crowds and Long Lines
Crowded stores, long checkout lines, and chaotic parking tons can quickly drain your energy and add unnecessary frustration. On-line shopping eliminates these challenges entirely. With a few clicks, you possibly can place orders and have them delivered to your door or directly to your recipient. This is very valuable during major holidays or sales occasions when physical stores change into packed with anxious shoppers.
Easier Worth Comparisons and Offers
Discovering one of the best deal in a physical store requires hopping from one location to a different, which takes time and effort. Online, you may simply evaluate prices throughout a number of retailers, read reviews, and access coupon codes or flash sales. Many browser extensions even automate this process, alerting you when a lower value is available elsewhere. This efficiency helps you stick to your budget and really feel more confident in your purchases.
Access to a Wider Choice
Local stores are limited by shelf space, but on-line retailers supply a virtually limitless inventory. Whether you are looking for a personalized item, a niche interest present, or something that ships internationally, on-line platforms provide access to products that is probably not available in your local area. This will increase your chances of discovering distinctive and significant items that stand out.
Present Wrapping and Direct Shipping Options
Many online retailers offer reward wrapping services and the option to ship directly to the recipient with a personalized note. This is a game-changer for many who live far from family and friends or are shopping for presents for a number of people. It saves time, effort, and shipping costs, all while making the process more seamless.
Read Critiques Earlier than You Buy
When shopping in stores, you are often shopping for based on packaging and presentation. Online, you may access buyer opinions, star ratings, and detailed product descriptions to guide your decisions. This minimizes the risk of disappointment and helps make sure the items you choose meet your expectations.
Set a Budget and Stick to It
On-line shopping platforms make it easier to control spending. You can filter by value range, apply promo codes, and keep away from impulse purchases that often occur when you‚Äôre browsing in a physical store. Some people additionally discover it useful to create a digital budget tracker to manage bills throughout reward-buying seasons.
On-line shopping offers a more peaceful, practical, and personalized way to shop for gifts. With the best approach, you may transform gift buying from a tense chore right into a smooth and satisfying experience.

author: Brieanna Charlebois; The Canadian Press
title: B.C. odour incidents spark questions around corporate ethics and communication
text:
Vancouver resident Robert Ford was heading to a yoga class Sunday morning when he smelled an odour he likened to "semi-burnt fuel."
As a member of council at his Kitsilano apartment building, he said he decided to check the boiler room, but it smelled fine.
"I was expecting something in there, so that was strange. I scratched my head and I went to the front door, which is right across from the beach, and it was 10 times more powerful outside," he said.
He immediately began searching online for an explanation but didn't find any answers until almost four hours later.
"I'm just kind of perplexed at how we can have such a nasty event with no public information hardly," he said.
It was one of two acrid odours that spread over parts of Metro Vancouver in less than a week, raising questions about corporate responsibility to inform the public when such events cause widespread concern and confusion but fall short of health and safety breaches.
The smell Ford referred to was revealed to be "an unplanned issue" with a Parkland fuel refinery processing unit in neighbouring Burnaby. The heavy stench, which Ford compared to jet fuel, blanketed parts of Metro Vancouver and caused more than 100 complaints from local residents.
It came just days after a gas leak from a FortisBC natural gas plant in nearby Delta, B.C., prompted criticisms from Mayor George Harvie and numerous residents that the utility didn't notify the public for more than four hours.
Harvie said the heavy odour caused stress and panic in the community, and a flood of calls to local police and fire departments hampered Delta's emergency response services.
A statement from Fortis said it was investigating after an elevated level of the odorant added to natural gas was unknowingly sent out in a controlled release of gas.
Carol Liao, a University of B.C. Sauder fellow at the Dhillon centre for business ethics, said these incidents are not necessarily matters for legislation, but rather about accountability and ethics.
"Businesses obviously need to obey bylaws, but they also need to understand that beyond that, there is a need to act responsibly to maintain public trust," she said.
"If a business is the cause of a terrible odour that's impacting the surrounding community and beyond, it should act as a good corporate citizen and own up to the problem right away, alert public officials, alert those possibly impacted and in harm's way, mitigate the damage and be accountable."
Harvie said he was involved in both incidents as Delta's mayor and as chair of Metro Vancouver's regional district.
"The difference between the two was (in) Metro Vancouver, air quality inspectors were on scene at the refinery, so we had more accurate information being fed back to us," he said.
Metro Vancouver monitors emissions of particulates, nitrogen dioxide and sulphur dioxide from the Parkland refinery, and the district has said air quality objectives for the contaminants weren't exceeded Sunday.
But, Harvie said the Fortis incident was different.
"The one from Fortis was very disturbing to me and it does speak a lot about corporate values (and) corporate responsibilities. They kept the information away from us," he said. "This was just unacceptable."
Harvie took to the social media site X after the smell covered an area stretching from the Tsawwassen ferry terminal to more than 30 kilometres away in Vancouver. The mayor said he had contacted FortisBC requesting an urgent followup meeting.
The Fortis statement released on Wednesday said work was being performed on new equipment, which was not connected to the gas system, and while a controlled release of gas was planned, the release of odour was not.
"Further review is underway to determine why there was an elevated level of odorant in the equipment," it said.
"Although the controlled release of gas at the interconnect station on Jan. 16 contained an elevated level of this odorant, it is not harmful and there are no immediate or long-term health effects."
Fortis said it had been in contact with local First Nations, municipal and emergency officials, including Harvie, as well as government regulators, to provide information on its response.
"We have also started a review of the incident and are working with relevant stakeholders during this process."
Kevin Farrow, technical director of Parkland, said in an interview that the refinery had paused processing operations earlier this month due to extreme cold weather.
"It was during that restart of the refinery, that one of the processing units had a plugged line, which ultimately led to the plume and odour that many experienced on Sunday," he said. "We've launched a review to better understand the root cause of what happened and how we got into this situation."
Parkland had issued an advisory on its website two days before the plume, alerting people who live nearby that they may notice noise and "higher than usual flare" from the facility.
In a timeline created by the refinery and sent to The Canadian Press, the company said the incident happened around 7:30 a.m. Sunday.
It said Metro Vancouver had been notified by 8:30 a.m., and by 9 a.m., the Burnaby Fire Department and the RCMP had created a perimeter around the facility as a safety precaution. The RCMP was called off at 11:26 a.m., while the fire department remained in place until 3:15 p.m., the timeline said.
The refinery's first public statement Sunday was issued at 11 a.m., notifying the public of an incident that cause elevated smoke, odours and particulate matter. That was followed up at 12:30 p.m. with a media advisory, announcing the shut down of operations.
While some, including Ford in Kitsilano, believe communication needs to come sooner to alleviate panic, Farrow said the "priority" of the refinery is to "communicate accurate and confirmed information to the public."
"We have that information now," he said. "We understand more, and we've begun to reach out to our community partners and to our neighbours, (and) you can expect a lot more information from the refinery in the coming days and weeks."
Farrow noted the refinery remains shut down but the company announced it would be conducting a "controlled and necessary operational procedure" on Thursday.
"We do not expect any impacts of the community. We're just making them aware, just in case anything were to occur," Farrow said.
Metro Vancouver also issued an updated air quality bulletin Wednesday night, saying it "will be closely monitoring" as the refinery conducts the operation "that may result in odour, smoke and flaring."
While some residents expressed concern about the announcement online, Liao applauded the move, saying an advanced public statement can be "immensely helpful in ensuring transparency and accountability to the surrounding communities."
"It helps avoid any public confusion and the tying up of resources such as 911 calls, while also mitigating risk," she said.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Jan. 25, 2024.
Brieanna Charlebois, The Canadian Press

author: world today news
title: Due to the amazing weather: next week it could be 25 degrees warm
text:
11.10.2024, 13:15 11.10.2024, 14:42
Friday started very cautiously across Switzerland: in many places there were dense clouds and in some cases rain. However, the weather will improve in the afternoon: ‚ÄúAs the day progresses, the weather will be very sunny with an intermediate high in the Lowlands and partly sunny in the Alps,‚Äù writes MeteoNews in a statement. In the south the 20 degree mark is even broken.
The weather forecast for the next six days.
There is one major event in particular to watch out for this weekend: the C/2023 A3 Tsuchinshan-ATLAS comet. This should be visible on Friday shortly after sunset (6:45pm). The best conditions for observation occur on Sunday night. Do you want to see the comet? Then you will find all important information about it here.
This is how the weekend will be Unfortunately, weather-wise, the weekend is more suitable for indoor activities. ‚ÄúFrom tomorrow, Saturday to Monday, clouds will dominate in the north; tomorrow, Saturday, there will be some fog in the Lowlands,‚Äù wrote MeteoNews. On Saturday, a water front will run through Switzerland from west to east, so it may be wet in many places.
But now for the good news: The sun will return later on Sunday. The weather models still do not give a clear picture for the beginning of next week, but it is likely that fog and sun will come again then. Due to a south facing trough over western Europe, there is a good chance of some sunshine.
Good news for next week: A trough over western Europe is bringing very mild air masses to Switzerland. Image: meteonews
Very mild air masses continue to arrive. So the temperature could rise back to 20 degrees even in the north. By the middle of the week, foehn winds and a possible 25 degrees will attract people to the Alpine valleys. (with them)

author: C√©sar H. S. Rezende
title: STF suspende sess√£o sobre incentivos fiscais para agrot√≥xicos | Exame
text: Rep√≥rter de agro e macroeconomia Publicado em 13 de junho de 2024 √†s 17h15. O Supremo Tribunal Federal (STF) suspendeu nesta quinta-feira, 13, o julgamento que decidia sobre a constitucionalidade de redu√ß√µes e isen√ß√µes de impostos concedidos para os agrot√≥xicos. Para o relator, o ministro Edson Fachin, uma audi√™ncia p√∫blica deve ser realizada para discutir de forma aprofundada o tema. A a√ß√£o foi apresentada pelo PSOL em 2016. O partido questionou um conv√™nio de 1997 do Conselho Nacional de Pol√≠tica Fazend√°ria (Confaz) que reduziu em 60% o ICMS que incide sobre agrot√≥xicos, al√©m de um decreto de 2011 ‚Äî posteriormente revogado ‚Äî que zerou o Imposto sobre Produtos Industrializados (IPI) que incide sobre parte dos produtos. Andamento do processo Oito ministros j√° votaram. O relator, ministro Edson Fachin, votou pela proced√™ncia do pedido. O ministro considerou que a utiliza√ß√£o de agrot√≥xicos acarreta "riscos √† sa√∫de humana e ao equil√≠brio da fauna e da flora", e que por isso n√£o devem receber benef√≠cios fiscais. Fachin foi acompanhado por C√°rmen L√∫cia. Gilmar Mendes abriu a diverg√™ncia e defendeu que a a√ß√£o seja rejeitada. Ao contr√°rio de Fachin, Gilmar avaliou que a isen√ß√£o "n√£o viola o direito √† sa√∫de ou ao meio ambiente equilibrado", por considerar que h√° um "minucioso regramento" para liberar os produtos e que o benef√≠cio diminui o pre√ßo dos alimentos. Ele foi acompanhado pelos ministros Cristiano Zanin, Dias Toffoli e Alexandre de Moraes. J√° o ministro Andr√© Mendon√ßa abriu uma terceira posi√ß√£o. Mendon√ßa considera que h√° um "processo de inconstitucionaliza√ß√£o", mas, ao inv√©s de invalidar as medidas, defendeu que o governo federal e os estados devem realizar, no prazo de 90 dias, uma reavalia√ß√£o da pol√≠tica. Fl√°vio Dino seguiu essa posi√ß√£o. Apesar de j√° ter votado, Mendon√ßa pediu destaque, o que levou o julgamento ao plen√°rio f√≠sico. Os ministros podem optar por repetirem os votos apresentados no ambiente virtual ou mudar de posi√ß√£o. Com informa√ß√µes da Ag√™ncia O Globo

author: @https://twitter.com/newbornsteve
title: Storm-tossed Lido Beach in Sarasota to be widened | WUSF
text:
Storm-tossed Lido Beach to be widened with a little federal help
The rebuilding of Sarasota's Lido Beach's storm-damaged sand dunes will also take place next year.
While Pinellas County residents will have to pay out of their own pockets for new sand on their beaches, the federal government is picking up the tab for a similar project in Sarasota.
The city of Sarasota will begin a renourishment of 1.2 miles of Lido Beach, which suffered significant erosion from last year's hurricanes.
But unlike Pinellas, the Army Corps of Engineers will pay for the $12 million project to deposit 200,000 to 300,000 cubic yards of sand dredged from New Pass.
Pinellas' plans have been stymied by a new Army Corps rule that every beachfront property owner has to agree to a permanent easement for the project to begin.
But city of Sarasota spokeswoman Jan Thornburg said the city received all easements that were required by the Army Corps in 2021. This is the second renourishment of Lido Beach paid for by the Army Corps.
"The city has a long-standing agreement with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for Lido Beach renourishment every five years," she said. "The city of Sarasota secured the necessary easements for the initial renourishment project with the (Army Corps) in 2021. Those easements remain in effect and continue to authorize access for both the beach berm and dune system, including access for future maintenance and storm risk management work."
The beach will remain open during the project, which is expected to last from this fall until spring of 2026.
New sand dunes will also be built next year. That will include a new vegetated dune system extending from the Lido Beach Pavilion to residential properties to the south.
The city got $12 million in disaster relief funds from the Corps after multiple hurricanes since 2021: $8 million in 2022, and an additional $4 million in 2025 to address the increased project costs from inflation and evolving designs.
‚ÄúThe renourishment of Lido Beach will not only improve the area for residents and visitors but also increase the resiliency of our coastal community,‚Äù said Mayor Liz Alpert, in a prepared statement. ‚ÄúWe thank our local, state, and federal partners for working alongside us in fortifying Lido Beach against sea level rise, tropical weather, and future climate impacts.‚Äù

author: Bill Shannon
title: Dinner, basket raffle to benefit chief's family after father killed in Christmas Eve fire
text:
WTAJ Altoona Dinner, basket raffle to benefit chief‚Äôs family after father killed in Christmas Eve fire Bill Shannon Thu, December 26, 2024 at 8:17 PM UTC 1 min read
CLEARFIELD COUNTY, Pa. (WTAJ) ‚Äî In continued support for the Winburne Fire Chief‚Äôs family, a spaghetti dinner and basket raffle will be held in Morrisdale.
The dinner and raffle are set to take place Sunday, Jan. 12 at the Morris Township Volunteer Fire Company Recreation Center (1104 Deer Creek Road, Morrisdale) from 1-4 p.m.
The meal comes with spaghetti and meatballs, salad, bread, a beverage and dessert. It‚Äôs $10 for adults and $5 for kids 12 and under and you can dine in or grab it to go. For more information or to donate for the basket raffle, click here .
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Volunteer Fire Chief‚Äôs father dies in Clearfield County fire, community mourns
All proceeds will go to benefit the Dunlap family after the family patriarch, Clifford, also known as Butch, died suddenly on Christmas Eve when his home caught fire and he was unable to get out. Butch is the father of Winburne‚Äôs Fire Chief, Robert.
Morris Township Volunteer Fire Company said in a post on their social media that Butch was a ‚Äúlife member‚Äù of the Winburne Fire Company. They said he dedicated many years of service to the community and was considered a ‚Äúpillar.‚Äù People knew Butch for his kindness and willingness to help anyone, they added.

author: Redacci√≥n GH
title: Deportan a Tom√°s Yarrington por frontera Tijuana - San Diego
text:
Deportan a Tom√°s Yarrington por frontera Tijuana - San Diego
El ex mandatario de Tamaulipas ser√° trasladado a la Fiscal√≠a General de la Rep√∫blica.
Tijuana BC.- El ex gobernador de Tamaulipas, Tom√°s Yarrington Ruvalcaba fue deportado a M√©xico desde Estados Unidos por las autoridades a trav√©s de la frontera San Diego - Tijuana.
Yarrington ser√≠a trasladado a las oficinas de la Fiscal√≠a General de la Rep√∫blica desde las 14:00 horas, de acuerdo a Expansi√≥n.
El ex mandatario hab√≠a sido condenado a 9 a√±os de c√°rcel federal por aceptar m√°s de 3.5 millones en sobornos y utilizar ese dinero para comprar propiedades en Estados Unidos, esta sentencia la habr√≠a esperado desde el 25 de marzo de 2021.
Te puede interesar: Tom√°s Yarrington: Dictan 9 a√±os de prisi√≥n en EU a exgobernador de Tamaulipas por aceptar 3.5 millones en sobornos
Enfrentar√° la justicia
Tom√°s a√∫n tendr√° que enfrentar a la justicia mexicana que el pasado diciembre le rechaz√≥ cancelar una orden de aprehensi√≥n vigente por un supuesto lavado de 12:7 millones de pesos y 450.000 d√≥lares.
Entre 1999 a 2004, Yarrington fue gobernador de Tamaulipas por el Partido Revolucionario Institucional, y el partido lo expuls√≥ en 2016.
Tras culminar su mandato, Tom√°s tuvo aspiraciones a la presidencia y fue precandidato del PRI en las elecciones del 2006, aunque perdi√≥ en la contienda interna de su partido.
Fue en 2017 cuando se le detuvo en Italia mientras viajaba con un nombre y pasaporte falso, as√≠ como otros documentos de identificaci√≥n.
Aunque Yarrington impugn√≥ su extradici√≥n, en el a√±o 2018 finalmente las autoridades italianas autorizaron su traslado a Estados Unidos.
